summary_piece.subtitle: Pobeda Automobile
summary_piece.text: In 1949, visitors examined a Pobeda automobile in Moscow. The design of this mass car began in December 1941, led by A. Lipgart at GAZ. Named "Pobeda" in anticipation of victory over Nazi Germany, the prototype was ready in 1944, with mass production starting post-war.

summary_piece.subtitle: Production and Sales
summary_piece.text: The Pobeda was the first passenger car in the USSR available for free sale and met global automobile standards. Over 12 years, more than 235,000 cars were produced, with exports to countries like Austria and Great Britain. It remains valued by collectors for its design and reliability.

summary_piece.subtitle: Post-War Industrial Growth
summary_piece.text: Despite difficulties, the USSR increased production of machine tools, turbines, and electrical appliances. In 1946, mass production of the GAZ-51 truck and GAZ M-20 "Pobeda" car began. The rural population became a key industrial resource, with peasants moving to cities for work.

summary_piece.subtitle: Reparations and Construction
summary_piece.text: Equipment from German factories, as part of reparations, aided industrial growth. Hundreds of thousands of captured Germans, Hungarians, Romanians, and Japanese worked on construction sites. New oil and gas fields were found in the Urals, and the Volga-Don Canal was built rapidly.

summary_piece.subtitle: Fourth Five-Year Plan
summary_piece.text: Over 6,000 enterprises were rebuilt during the Fourth Five-Year Plan. By 1950, industrial output exceeded pre-war levels by 70%, and in the Baltic republics and Moldova by 2-3 times.

summary_piece.subtitle: Cold War Military Modernization
summary_piece.text: The Cold War led to increased military production to prevent a repeat of the 1941 invasion. The army was modernized with new tanks (IS-4, T-54), the Kalashnikov AK rifle, MiG-15 and MiG-17 jet fighters, and modern warships.

summary_piece.subtitle: Soviet Atomic Project
summary_piece.text: The main goal was to eliminate the US nuclear monopoly. L. Beria supervised the Soviet atomic project, with research led by I. Kurchatov, Y. Khariton, S. Korolev, and M. Keldysh. In 1948, the USSR launched its first ballistic missile R-1, and in August 1949, the atomic bomb was successfully tested.
